designations.source: A review of the Hemiptera of Great Britain: The Aquatic and Semi-aquatic Bugs
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national status of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs using IUCN methodology for assessing threat. It covers all species of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs (Heteroptera) in Great Britain, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and non-native species. A.A. Cook November 2015.
designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: Taxa which do not qualify for Lower Risk (conservation dependent), but which are close to qualifying for Vulnerable. In Britain, this category includes species which occur in 15 or fewer hectads but do not qualify as Critically Endangered, Endangered or Vulnerable.
designations.comments: There are 8 post 1989 records for the Lincolnshire, North Norfolk, Suffolk and Kent coasts and 7 for the  Cumbrian and South Lancashire coasts. C. pilosus is confined to saltmarshes, which are threatened by sea level rise, erosion by storms and pollution. All recent records are for the south east and north west coasts of England. This could be an artefact of under-recording although other saldid species found in coastal habitats, including saltmarshes, have been recorded since 1989 from many areas outside these two regions and, as shore bugs go, C. pilosus is a relatively conspicuous species. C. pilosus has not been recorded in Wales since 1946 (Howe 2004). It is a very local species on the western limit of its range in GB and does not fall far short of a threat status. On the basis of AOO (<2,000km2) and projected risk to saltmarsh habitats it is assessed as NT.

designations.designation: Nationally Rare. Includes Red Listed taxa
designations.designation_description: Nationally Rare - Occurring in 15 or fewer hectads in Great Britain. Includes rare species qualifying under the main IUCN criteria.
